newsitem.title: SLOVENIA: Slovenia's bank sell-off possible next year-banker.
newsitem.headline: Slovenia's bank sell-off possible next year-banker.

text.p: Privatisation of Slovenia's biggest bank Nova Ljubljanska Banka (NLB) and the country's third-ranked bank Nova Kreditna Banka Maribor (NKBM) could start in 1998, NLB chief Marko Voljc said on Saturday.

"Presumably the law on the sale of state assets will be adopted this year and that would set the stage for bank privatisation," Voljc told reporters following a closed meeting of central European bank executives at the Slovenian Adriatic resort of Portoroz.
"It is possible (bank) privatisation could start next year," Voljc added.

The green light for privatisation of the two unlisted banks was given on Thursday when the Bank of Slovenia established that the two banks fulfilled conditions to end a state restructuring programme which started in 1993.
The restructuring, deemed necessary because bank balance sheets were tainted by problem loans to old public sector enterprises, was managed by Slovenia's Bank Rehabilitation Agency.
During the restructuring, the government took over most of the two banks' non-performing assets from Slovenia's pre-independence days.
The government plans to privatise both banks, but has not yet set out a timetable for the selloff or how it will be carried out.

Charles Dallara, managing director of the Washington-based Institute of International Finance, pointed out the importance of privatisation which leads to ownership that "enables managers to manage the bank (solely) in the interest of commercial performance and of shareholders' benefit.
"The banks in the (central European) region are very well positioned to compete effectively in the years ahead also on an international scale," Dallara said.
NLB's market share in Slovenia is 28 percent, while NKBM has an 11.5 percent share.
There are currently 28 banks in Slovenia, many of which are privately owned.
